entries.meaning: A small amount of something, especially paste.
examples: Put a dob of butter on the potato, please.

verbs.description: dob (third-person singular simple present dobs, present participle dobbing, simple past and past participle dobbed)

entries.meaning: (slang, chiefly Australia, New Zealand) To report (a person) to someone in authority for a wrongdoing.
examples: I’ll dob on you if you break in.
You dobbed me in! — I never did!

entries.meaning: (slang, chiefly Australia) To do one's share; to contribute.
examples: We all dobbed in for a gift when he retired.

entries.meaning: (slang, chiefly Australia) To nominate a person, often in their absence, for an unpleasant task.
examples: I arrived just after the meeting had started and found myself dobbed in to take the minutes.

description: Short for do our best. dyb (or dib) and dob were used as abbreviated forms of do your best and do our best in certain Scout chants.

verbs.description: dob (third-person singular simple present dobs, present participle dobbing, simple past and past participle dobbed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, sometimes humorous) In the scouting movement, to chant dob to indicate that one will do one's best to follow the scouting laws.
examples: I used to get through the dibbing and dobbing all right but during the howling I usually rolled over backwards.
